reviewText:
Greed Corp is a turn-based strategy game that you can play either singleplayer, vs up to three pcs, or multiplayer.  The story is a basic one for each of the four playable groups; however, their differences in-game are graphical only.  The full story took me around twelve or so hours to complete.

Greed Corp uses a hexagon-tile battlefield in which you can use the land in order to gain more money to buy units and buildings.  However, the more you use the land to gain money, the more it deteriorates and disappears completely.  It is a delicate balance between building units to conquer land and kill enemy units, using the land for money before your opponents do, and conserving the strength and number of tiles in your control.  The win condition is to be the last player left standing.

I greatly enjoyed this game and would recommend it to anyone who enjoys a turn-based strategy game.  Learning how to play the game is fairly easy, but there is definitely strategy to be had in this game.
voteText: 20 of 22 people (91%) found this review helpful

reviewText: A fantastic indie game with a moral that, though prevalent throughout the campaign, doesn't overshadow the wonderful mechanics of the game itself. The game is focused around a world made up of tall hexagon-shaped pillars which stand in the middle of a massive ocean. The various factions which occupy the world have finally begun to reach the bottom of the seemingly endless supply of resources in the ground and their constant drilling and mining has caused large portions of the world to simply collapse into the ocean. The turn-based mechanics are easy to grasp and are complex enough to let even veterans of such games enjoy the fun. The graphics quality is fantastic with a low setting capable of running on very low end machines. The game does possess a significant amount of replayability thanks to the multiplayer mode although the single player campaign is reasonably fun the second time around.

reviewText: You know, even with how obscure this game is, it's possibly one of the best strategy games I have ever played just for the pure sake that it's so simple, but so mentally, strategically challenging. Territory only lasts for so long, since you harvest money from the land, and that land is slowly destroyed because of it. The war can only go for so long before somebody's section crumbles and falls down into the endless abyss of clouds.

reviewText:
greed corp is a turn based hex game but different to most strategy games. the difference is its much more simple. but that is what makes it awesome! so simple yet so fun.

the game takes place on some world were either incredibly cute walker like robots or people piloting incredibly cute walker type machines live. the place they live is also so way high up in the sky that it would probably take half an hour to hit the ground if you fell off. and its divided into hexes that you fight over.

the fighting or gameplay is very simple. you can either build a barracks or harvester to start off with. harvesters harvest the floor to make you money but also destroy the floor as they do it. and when a piece of land is destroyed enough it falls down into the clouds taking everything with it.

in other words harvesters can be an effective weapon for destroying your foes land while making you money in the process.

when you build  a barracks you can build walkers. walkers can claim 1 hex forward per turn and battle your opponents walkers.

except the battles are  little more just basic math as the walkers simply cancel each other out. so who ever has more walkers will win.

and once you claim a hex you can build on it also the more hexes you have the more money you get per turn.

the 2 other things you can build are the air ship and the cannon. the air ship transports all the walkers on one hex across the map and are the only way of getting around late game as nearly everything is broken... most of the time.
the cannon on the other hand is used to shoot a hex. when a hex is shot it moves down one level getting more broken.

it is the same thing as what a harvester does and when a hex losses all of its levels it crumbles into the clouds. cannons also kill 5 walkers so your foes will have less men.

so that's basically how the game goes you harvest stuff break the land while doing it then get cannons and air ships and either try and conquer your opponents land or break it.

also the theme of the game is very nice with the greedy theme being taken very light heartedly and the way fighting works having no actual fighting or blood at all. if I gave this game a ERSB rating it would probably be PG for very mild violence.

as for the real rating I give it a 8/10 and a 9/10 if its on sale for $3 or less. for it being a really good game to play with friends
but maybe not so much with sore losers. it also has a great steampunk style awesome funky soundtrack and last of all great mechanics.

reviewText:
This a small TBS worth due to it's simplicity and effectiveness in its mechanics. It is a Risk styled game, where you control a faction that must destrtoy all enemy factions in a hexagonal tile base map. In order to do thta, players must generate income, done so by placing Harvesters accross the field; the important bit here is that harvesters generate income by smashing the tile where it was placed, in addition to all adjacent tiles; every time a tile is smashed, it lowers it's height, reaching a point where the tile fractures and subsequently collapses - what this means is that, as income is generated, the battlefield gets eventually destroyed, and by the end game, its rather common that only a couple of tiles remain in the whole battlefield.

The game is entirely deterministic - no dice is rolled at all. A duel is resoleved by the size of the attacking force, with the casualties determined by simple substraction (invading force unit count - defending force unit count). Addionally, all maps are perfectly symmetrical. This leaves the game's conflict to be entirely resolved by player's strategy and nothing else. This is easier said than done, however, as the tile destruction inflicted by harvesters (and player-deployed artillery) constantly change the battlefield, your strategy is in an ever constant need for change.

The game lacks a bit of variety, so it can easily become a little repetitive - this is not Chess nor Go in regards to depth. An expande sequel would have been indeed welcome, but this never came to pass. I still recommend it heartily if you are a fan of TBS.

reviewText:
I bought this game during the 2014 holiday sale when I had a few bucks left over and nothing else on my wish list. I am very glad I got it now, as opposed to the other prospects I had lined up.

This game plays like Risk, but has some really awesome new mechanics that make the game worth getting. The biggest mechanic is the game's titular use of greed to change the landscape: you can use harvesters to work the land and get money, but ever time you do, the land they stand on is slowly lowered until it collapses. This introduces some seriously awesome strategies in the game; one time I planted a harvester in the middle of an enemy island in order to collapse it and take out everyone on the island. I didn't have to use any of my troops or engage in a time-consuming siege- all I had to do was attack an unprotected square my opponent had left neglected, plant a harvester there, and laugh as the ground literally crumbled under their troops.

This review is getting really long, but let me just tell you this before I finish: GET THIS GAME. It's definitely worth it, and the only things wrong with it aren't even part of the game itself, they're problems with the developer, whom has discontinued supporting the game and thusly Greed Corp's servers are dead.

The campaign is about 10 hours of gameplay, and it's pretty nice. However, the true worth of this game comes from the multiplayer, which can still happen... we always find a way. My only regrets is that this game doesn't have any steam workshop support, and that the developer seems to have done a disappearing act.

reviewText:
Greed Corp.

Think Industrial Revolution. Big Band Music. Cute clanky droids with funny animation and a easy strategy game.

In King Arthur you are playing with knight figures on a vast battle field. Greed Corp, you are playing with droids on a varying platform arena. (So to speek)

King Arthur to overwhelming for you?

Still looking for a strategy game that won't give you a migraine?

Then Greed Corp is your cup of tea.

It's more of a low keyed strategy game and it is good.

You won't be dissapointed :)

Outta 5 stars (5 being best, 1 being worst)

Greed Corp gets a cute **** 4 stars :)
A very good turn based tactical game, limited building options actually adds to the strategy.
It's like an updated version of Sean o' Connor's Windows Games: Slay"."
A rather simple very well made turn based strategy which turns resource generation into your most leathal offensive weapon

The quintessential display of gentlemanliness is to sip Pimms on a sunny afternoon whilst discussing the stock market with your good friend Quincent, and taking turns to annihilate each other in this 21st century substitute for chess.  Classy and sopisticated, this is a gaming gem you will always treasure.

A neat little turn-based strategy game. Resource harvesting dramatically changes the field of play, which means every decision has a bit more weight. None of the factions has an advantage over another. Certainly not as deep as Civ, but still impressively replayable.\n\nRecommended for fans of board/tabletop games and jackhammers.
Nice and innovative strategy game.

Simple, quick, turn-based strategy makes Greed Corp a great change of pace from most games available.  If you like turn-based strategy or board games like Risk – this game may be right up your alley and is worth about $7.50.
It's actually a really good, fun strategy game. It's simple to learn. I taught my six year old brother how to play, and we had a great time in the two-player mode.
if slavoj zizek were still alive he'd state this game in every one of his presentations as a prime example of why capitalism kills and so on and so on

reviewText: Great turnbased strategy-puzzle type game that is unlike anything I have ever played.

A new take on an old formula. It's RISK gets greedy in this turn-based strategy game. The dice roll mechanics are simplified to a straight walker vs walker" (the only unit) numbers game with the edge going to the attacker. But then add in buildings
date: the most iconic of which is the harvester. It adds resources each turn that you can use to build more buildings and walkers
recommended: but it also lowers the tile it's on -- until it crumbles and "falls off" the map
hoursPlayed: taking any of your units and buildings (or the enemy's) on that tile with it. Now start considering those as offensive weapons and the game just got way more interesting."

reviewText:
It's like a cooperatve turn-based board game like carcassonne but instead of helping each other build things, you:

- Help yourself (or your opponents) destroy their natural resources
- Build armies with said opponent's resources and use them to kill said opponent
- Tactically shape the land to your advantage by destroying all of it
- Build structures (that desrtoy things)

Now for the actual gameplay.

The game features only a few things you can build/do, but the combination of them and the landscape has many tactical possibilities to offer.

- Build armories to make walkers
- Bulld walkers to seize terriroty and kill other walkers
- Build harvesters to strip mine entire chunks of land for money, or use them as an offensive tool to gradually destroy th very land your opponents stand on
- Build cannons to shoot things
- Build carriers to lead aerial strikes over inpassable chasms or just a lot of unclaimed land

The verdict?

buy it, but wait until it goes on sale. (holiday sale anyone?) You'll need friends that own it too, the singleplayer campaign is grindy to say the least. Don't buy it if you hate strategy games. Worth 8-9 U.S. dollars, priced at 10. After all, it truly is...

Turn based strategy at its finest"."
Nice and simple indie strategy game with hexagonal maps that shatter when mined for resources.

reviewText:
Great little strategy game with an excellent aesthetic.

The gameplay is a fresh variation on classic turn-based strategy action; you need to harvest resources to pay for units, but harvesting will also damage (and eventually destroy) the very land you stand on. It's all about balance.

Good scenarios and maps, a great visual style, and awesome retro ragtime soundtrack. It's just a shame the online play is so dead.

reviewText: A clever tactical title, with a touch of environmentalism sprinkled in via one of the main game mechanics. You are awarded funds each turn, and said funds increase over the course of the game, but you can accelerate your inflow by placing towers that degrade the map. They can also be used to craft the map state in a way that changes the flow of battle, even if it turns into a waiting game near the end to simply get enough funds to make a decisive strike. You have to be conscious of how the pieces are placed on the board, and how things will likely change in the near future. You'll need to think ahead to play this game, but if you get the hang of it, it feels pretty good to pull off an effective strategy.

reviewText: Greed Corp is akin to checkers, easy to get into but very difficult to master. At first glance, this game may appear to be overly casual. There are two building types in the game, one mortar unit type, one attack unit type, and one transportation unit type. Play it a few times and you will come to realize that this game is anything but casual, frustrating even. To win at all, you will have to be very careful of where you place your mining units which can collapse the platform your other units are standing on. Play recklessly and you end up trapped with nothing left to do but pray for a miracle. I’ll conclude by saying this, if you can stand playing checkers for a dozen hours or more, this game is right up your alley.

reviewText:
I first found this game on Android and it recently came up on a Humble bundle. I must admit I very much doubted that it'd scale well to PC, after all there are so many games that just don't scale to a PC well. Greed Corp isn't an exception to this. It's begging for a windowed mode. Let me explain.

The strategy and gameplay is still pretty good it's a nice game to just sit and play. It's very area or control based, but doesn't tax your concentration too much. You could easily be playing this whilst watching something else on your computer. If you could window the game it'd be great to multi-task on the computer with. Sadly, I don't seem to be able to do that here.

Personally, I'd recommend putting the game on your phone or tablet rather than PC. It's a decent little game and has a fair play time (at least two hours to complete the campaign), but isn't really a fully fledged PC game.

reviewText: Don't be fooled: although this game is listed as available to download, it is actually only available to play on a series of 3,458 gold-plated floppy disks, each one delivered by specially-trained gibbons who ride on the back of unicorns. I thought this would be a memorable experience in and of itself, but it turns out that gibbons ♥♥♥♥ everywhere and I don't have a 3.5 disk drive anymore. Also
date: the unicorns stamped my cat to death in a fight over whether Justin Bieber or One Direction have better songs. 7 out of a possible 3 million ornate ming vases."

reviewText: Oh gee, one, really obnoxious ragtime piano track that plays for every mission. Thank heavens there is a music volume option in the settings.

reviewText: Extremely simple yet amazingly satisfying. A simple little strategy game that has an interesting twist. Has multiplayer and the atmosphere to the game is really cool. Nothing like destroying the land right under your enemy while listening to smooth jazz. I just wish the game was more deep and had more content because they could have taken this game far.
voteText: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is essentially a computerized board game. Is it good? I don't really know.

Here's the problem: there's no online strategy guides available, and nobody has really done any proper analysis of the game. This makes it hard to really get a handle on the strategy. Even if you do spend the time to figure it out yourself, the odds are pretty low that anyone else on your friends list will have done the same.

So you're faced with a problem: If you play as a novice, you won't understand the strategy well enough and the outcome will seem almost arbitrary; and if you learn to play the game well, you'll have nobody to play against.

reviewText: A challenging yet fun game were thinking a few steps ahead is key.  A bit like simplifided chess with explosions and a crumbling playing field that you are taking right out from under your own feet!
이건 .. 그냥 겨울시즌 세일 이벤트땜에 ..;;
Great concept and beautiful visuals. Game mechanics distilled to their minimum, and it works great. Well worth a number of hours of your time.
Its an amazing little game for an amazing little price, well worth the Moneys in my opinion.\nHas a few minor hiccups but overall Great Game. 9/10
An outstanding and very original indie RTS, great value for the price!

Greed Corp is very simple. That said, it is also very cheap. There are no unique units and the different races" are really just different skins of the same things. You're not going to be incredibly drawn into Greed Corp's campaign
date: but playing with friends is where the game really shines. It is infuriating and unbelieveably fun backstabbing each other
recommended: and watching a well-timed cannon blast cause a chain reaction that knocks a majority of your buddy's land (and in turn
hoursPlayed: resources) out of the sky is ridiculously satisfying.\n\nSure you aren't going to get a tremendous amount of hours out of it
voteText: but Greed Corp is great for a quick couple games to sit back and banter with your friends."

reviewText: If you like losing because CRAP you accidentally built an extractor on your last bit of land, this game may be for you.
Fun and quite tactical. Nice way to put in those boring times.
So simple yet so effective!\nYou should buy this.
Like chess on crack...it's hot!

A simple strategy game that's addictive! You need to manage your territory to harvest credits to support your Empire while keeping some ground to survive! A must play for gamers into simple turn strategy games.
Definitely a game worth buying. I got it out of a Humble Bundle, but definitely would pay full price for it now that I've played it.
This is a great game for the boardgame-lover out there. It's like Settlers of Catan"
date: assuming Catan was high up in the clouds and instead of settling it
recommended: you were actively destroying 90% of it to fund a war. Good times."

reviewText:
War leaves nothing. Even the triumph doesn't leave you anything.
Our effort to survive will eventually take everything we have. But we have to keep this war.

Most of all, the 'crucial' harvest mechanic inspired by the industrial revolutions and their destructive effects on the environment" is quite impressive. Seeing still working harvester fading off under the clouds with the fragments of the land just collapsed by the destructive effect of the harvester itself hurts somewhere inside of me every time."

A quirky, inventive strategy game that manages to stand out from the usual Strategy routine. Its simplicity and streamlined mechanics are akin to Chess, which is simultaneously what appeals and limits it. The nature of a constantly disintegrating game world is a powerful image that makes the game one you'll remember.
独特のルールで楽しめるターン制の陣取り合戦\n複数人でオンラインでもオフラインでも楽しめる\nシングルモードで新MAPをいくつか開放できる
Nice turn-based strategy game, very original and funny.

An easy-to-pick-up strategy game that explores the balance between conquest and survival.  You're fighting for control of an island, but to raise the funds necessary to build your expensive army and maintain your costly defenses, you need to sacrifice your own territory.  There are only a handful of units and skirmishes are simplified to battles of numbers, but the constantly-shifting landscape and the emphasis on proper budgeting encourage deep long-term planning.

A quirky, inventive strategy game that manages to stand out from the usual Strategy routine. Its simplicity and streamlined mechanics are akin to Chess, which is simultaneously what appeals and limits it. The nature of a constantly disintegrating game world is a powerful image that makes the game one you'll remember.
独特のルールで楽しめるターン制の陣取り合戦\n複数人でオンラインでもオフラインでも楽しめる\nシングルモードで新MAPをいくつか開放できる
Like chess on crack...it's hot!
Fun and quite tactical. Nice way to put in those boring times.

This indie game is a superb light turn-based strategy game, where four different armies clash over hexagonal pillars standing above the clouds. All four sides are functionally the same, but with differing aesthetics. Balance is vital, however, as the money-making harvesters you build will eventually destroy the hexagons around them. As such, the need for money creates a conflict with the need to have an actual battlefield to war upon. This need for balance produces a very unique array of strategies to employ. The music and night-time ambience really adds to the feel of the game, as do the army designs. A light-hearted game that nonetheless provides a challenge thanks to its unique take on resource gathering one so often sees in strategy games.
Fun little game, to brake away from the norm with.  SImple enough anyone can pick it up and play.

War leaves nothing. Even the triumph doesn't leave you anything.
Our effort to survive will eventually take everything we have. But we have to keep this war.

Most of all, the 'crucial' harvest mechanic inspired by the industrial revolutions and their destructive effects on the environment" is quite impressive. Seeing still working harvester fading off under the clouds with the fragments of the land just collapsed by the destructive effect of the harvester itself hurts somewhere inside of me every time."
So simple yet so effective!\nYou should buy this.

A simple strategy game that's addictive! You need to manage your territory to harvest credits to support your Empire while keeping some ground to survive! A must play for gamers into simple turn strategy games.
Such a fun game. So glad Steam had it on sale. I really enjoy playing the different levels and multiplayer. You should try.
Relaxing board game. Probably would be better played on a tablet.
very unique gameplay. 5/5 stars!
Hex-shaped, lovingly stylized, turn-based goodness.

Took me a few years but I finally had the time to beat this game.  This game is a great fun game of tactics.  It would be or maybe it is I am no sure an ios game something you sit at the airport challenging people online or even hotsit.  The only problem thing is this game is easy to learn so it makes it simple.  This is a well made game just a bit simple for season gamers.

Cute, Simple, but incredibly shallow. It's a turn-based strategy game entirely centered around territory control - the fastest way to eliminate your foes is simply to destroy the land beneath them, which is a feat made incredibly easy by the cheapest building - the resource harvester.\n\nCatch it on sale or avoid it entirely.
Very enjoyable grid strategy game with good A.I. opposition.
Pretty decent game for the price. I don't usually like turn-based strategy games but this one is definitely an exception.
It's like playing with tiny cute robot Skaven mining for warpstone!

a fun little game, especially great when you have friends to play against, the game really shines in multiplayer. it reminds me of a game of chess, a thinking mans game with many tense moments. the destruction feature definately puts a sense of urgency to the game, as it is a way to both earn money and destroy enemies.\nThere are so many different elements and features to consider in a game of greed corp that you can never really cover all possibilities, and it is a game of deception and feigning attacks just as much as it is a game of tactical and economical prowess. the feeling of winning a game with a chain reaction of crumbing tiles is an amazing feeling, and you definately feel like you have achieved something when you win.\nIt is almost inherent that these indie games dont last as long as their AAA counter parts, but i guarrentee that months or even YEARS after buying this game, you will have an urge to play a match or two, just to get that feeling back... speaking of which. :)

Greed Corp is a turn-based strategy game, based on controlling territory then destroying it for fun and profit. The rules of the game are pretty simple, but the strategy remains deep. That alone makes this game worth considering for strategy fans. I really have no issues with how the game works mechanically. The story's uninteresting and unimportant. I usually ended up turning the music and sound off; they don't add much. The graphics look pretty good, with one complaint: it's very hard to tell which building does what from appearance alone, which is sometimes problematic.\n\nFans of slower strategy games should look at picking this one up. There seems to be lots of support for online play, if you're in to that. The biggest issue I would worry about is that there aren't any extra play modes, and there's no difference in the factions, so you may not get much milage out of the game if you find the battles boring. $10 may be a little much, but it's worth getting if you find it cheap.
Pretty good game for under $5.  No randomness, simple but satisfying strategy and an easy-to-learn system.  The game should be an android app.

Four very distinctly and nicely stylized factions battle it out for control of the quickly-dwindling resources to the very fitting old-timey tunes played during each battle. For as nice the game looks, however, there isn't much to it once you've scratched the surface. In essence, Greed Corp is a poor man's Risk, providing a painfully simple and straightforward unit creation and combat system with predictable AI, so each battle pretty much plays itself once you know what to do to counter the enemy's moves. It's a fun little time waster if you can pick it up on the cheap, but I can't recommend it for the default ten dollar price tag.
Original, challenging, accessible, and most importantly; fast-paced. A rare quality among turn based strategy games. Worth every penny.

Greed Corp is a fantastic strategy game that depicts a land war in which every turn destroyes more and more of the remaining world and even winning is bittersweet. With a charming steampunk style and big band backing music, GReed Corp is something you can dive into and enjoy throught its extensive campaign.
It's a very unique game. Better than I expected.
Fast, fun, challenging but not punishing, short matches but satisfying victories. Way more addicting than I thought it would be!
Nice turn-based strategy game, very original and funny.
Simple, beautiful strategy.  An excellent implementation of easy to learn

GreedCorp is a very interesting title. Players battle over the most important resource of all. LAND! Unfortunately, under all the land is just sky. So every time you destroy land you fall into oblivion! This game has some pretty awesome vibes to it. The gameplay  mechanics are deffinately new and fun. There are multiple corporations battling over what little land is left. This game has a beefy single player campaign, you won't be dissapointed! ~PR0XIDIAN
It's like playing with tiny cute robot Skaven mining for warpstone!

a fun little game, especially great when you have friends to play against, the game really shines in multiplayer. it reminds me of a game of chess, a thinking mans game with many tense moments. the destruction feature definately puts a sense of urgency to the game, as it is a way to both earn money and destroy enemies.\nThere are so many different elements and features to consider in a game of greed corp that you can never really cover all possibilities, and it is a game of deception and feigning attacks just as much as it is a game of tactical and economical prowess. the feeling of winning a game with a chain reaction of crumbing tiles is an amazing feeling, and you definately feel like you have achieved something when you win.\nIt is almost inherent that these indie games dont last as long as their AAA counter parts, but i guarrentee that months or even YEARS after buying this game, you will have an urge to play a match or two, just to get that feeling back... speaking of which. :)

Great fun.\nAn easy to play strategy gem.
A simple, yet satisfying strategy game with good multiplayer.

This is a great little game that will keep you going back for more, its addictive gameplay, although i could only play a few levels before my head was hurting. It seems there is not much of a multiplayer population for this game. Which is a big lettdown for me, as there is only computer left to play.
I found this to be a pretty boring game the speed you play at and the objective of the game just diddn't match up for me the *Race* i was exspecting to feel never kicked in....
Весёлая игра! Советую всем!

A very different kind of strategy game, based on non-sustainable resource farming, height advantages and tactical demolition. The story is only there if you want it, presented in big ungainly paragraphs of text, like in Braid. However, the jazzy big band music adds a really nice 'booming 20s' feel to the industrialized madness!

As mentioned in several other reviews on this game, there are times when the slightly unforgiving gameplay mechanics create a stalemate; where the first person to move will ultimately lose the match. I have been observing some of the pro players of this game, who appear to have got the turn-based mechanics down to a math.

But if you're a fan of cartoony little robot characters, gramophone jazz, or just sick of hearing about global warming and dwindling rainforests, this game is for you! 3/5 from me.

As deep as chess with a 3D twist, stylish graphics, and as addictive as a sneeze.

From the music to the gameplay this game is just damn fun.

If you like stategy games, and one with a lot of replayablity this is a diamond in the rough and worth it at any price.

Simple to learn but harder to master.\nThis is a fun little turn based game (I'm not usually a fan but I like this).\nGood to play vs your friends & play the single player campaign to unlock more maps!
surprisingly fun. not sure if worth 10$, but definitely at least 5

Not only this is a great turn-based strategy game with a different and fun mechanic but it's also a nice analogy for humankind and what we're doing to our planet...\n\nMorality aside, the way you gather resources by slowly destroying the very map hexagons you need to stand on and/or build is genius! It opens up different ways of destroying your enemy while making you think carefully to see if you're not dooming yourself as well.

This game could be some much BETTER in 2D. Seriously. It's a nice clever turn-based board game. But all these 3D bells and whistles are hurting so much while adding... um, nothing? Sure, elevation is a game mechanic here, but it has a discrete value that could be represented by some tokens in 2D. So please, please give me a flat fast-paced version of this and I'll play it. Currect slugish 3D incarnation? No way.
What's that old saying? A minute to learn
date: a lifetime to master"?\n\nYep. That's Greed Corp. Anyone that likes turn-based games in that follows suit of strategic board games (Best I can compare it to would be Stratego mixed with Heroscape) would love this game. The maddening AI makes for long hours of gameplay in campaign mode
recommended: but as with most board games
hoursPlayed: the real joy is in the multiplayer. (Online and Local available.)"

reviewText: we love this game, buy it and make us even happier!\nRick n Sal'

Now I can tell you, it's an ingenious game. Everything boils down to tactics, thinking ahead and making mistakes. Well, at least i'm good at the last part, but it's still a great game!

Recommended for everyone who likes turn based strategy!

Very good and unique strategy game. Definitely worth buying.
Great fun.\nAn easy to play strategy gem.

Greed corp is a boardgame style battle between greedy little robots.. I always think im gonna do good, then i get super smashed and lose.. it's got a cool vibe to the game play, even tho i suck I still think its fun..Its a good game to play on a rainy evening when you run out of things to do.. the greed over takes yer mind and you really gotta plan yer attack.. games that take skill instead of luck always catch my eye more than stuff like magic cards, where it doesnt matter what you do, cuz its all random and super weak.. 7/10

This game is unimaginably good. Plot, music, steampunky atmosphere and, of course, deeply tactical gameplay. A must have, I'd say.

The strategy of this game never opened up for me. All of the factions are the same and there are really only a handful of options at your disposal. The mechanic of destroying your land as you try to fight for more is really interesting and I'd love to see it built on more but it is never really fulfilled in this game.

This is a really fabulous strategy game, and the look/feel is unique and really special.  I love the music!  You should get it while it's still on sale, though it's not a bad value at full price either!

dont really know what to say about this one

its kinda meh. not bad, not good but not my sort of game. i suppose it might be worth a little look

COMPLETIONISTS NOTE: you'll need 3 freinds

Just went through the single player campaign.  I must say I had no challenge.  The AI is not that bad, but the levels are not designed to give you a real challenge.\nThe fist few levels are fun, but the objectives are always the same.  This is a TBS I will not go back to play.
You can't beat a good turn based hex grid game like this. It's apparent simplicity masks some serious tactical depth and frankly, I'm terrible at it!
An enjoyable simple, pleasing to the eye Turn Based Stratagy game, Simple Tactics but it works well for a game like this, quick to learn and get into games with friends. True Value = $10
Simple rules, deep strategy. Innovative multiparty multiplayer, any combination friend/online/AI. Dutch Developer! Dutch Developer! Did i say Dutch Developer?
This is like a fun little board game turned into a great looking computer game.
Love this game. It starts off pretty easy and all of a sudden hits a brick wall of impossibly hard. Fun for the first half of the game though.
Fun to play with friends. Simple rules, but a lot of tactics.

very unique gameplay. 5/5 stars!

Very addictive
Very fun strategy game that doesn't take 17 hours to play one game, in fact, most games can be played in 20 minutes!
Deceptively simple on the outside, Greed Corp will put all your strategic thinking skills to the test in its complex gameplay.
More complex than first glance reveals. I enjoy the subtlety that separates win from loss.  Forethought and practice are key and luck has a place as well.  Hone your skills with a friend.

This was actually a lot more fun than I expected.  It's a pretty great turn-based strategy game that scratches that RTS itch I get without getting bogged down in unnecessary complexity.  It's a simple, well-executed concept.

I love this game. GET IT! It's a turn based strategy game that's unlike any other PC game i've played. It's very quick to learn how to play the game, but the strategy is more complex and will change based on who you play, and what kind of strategy they choose.

Greed Corp is a turn-based strategy game, based on controlling territory then destroying it for fun and profit. The rules of the game are pretty simple, but the strategy remains deep. That alone makes this game worth considering for strategy fans. I really have no issues with how the game works mechanically. The story's uninteresting and unimportant. The graphics look pretty good, with one complaint: it's very hard to tell which building does what from appearance alone, which is sometimes problematic.\n\nFans of slower strategy games should look at picking this one up. There seems to be lots of support for online play, if you're in to that. The biggest issue I would worry about is that there aren't any extra play modes, and there's no difference in the factions, so you may not get much milage out of the game if you find the battles boring. $10 may be a little much, but it's worth getting if you find it cheap.

Four very distinctly and nicely stylized factions battle it out for control of the quickly-dwindling resources to the very fitting old-timey tunes played during each battle. For as nice the game looks, however, there isn't much to it once you've scratched the surface. In essence, Greed Corp is a poor man's Risk, providing a painfully simple and straightforward unit creation and combat system with predictable AI, so each battle pretty much plays itself once you know what to do to counter the enemy's moves. It's a fun little time waster if you can pick it up on the cheap, but I can't recommend it for the default ten dollar price tag.
very unique gameplay. 5/5 stars!
Hex-shaped, lovingly stylized, turn-based goodness.

A great little turn-based, board-game style strategy game. Very simple to learn but very absorbing and a lot of fun. Take turns moving around a hex-board, extracting resources (which slowly destroys the landscape) and buying units, artillery or air-lifts to beat your enemies. At the end of the round very little of the map will remain.\n\nThe game really comes into it's own when playing with 3 other human players. Online play is integrated into Steam so use the 'Invite' option from your friends list.
this game is very fun. If you have the money you should buy it
Fun with friends, a game we commonly go back to, decent strategy
Nice board esque video game. Better with friends, wish they could make an actual board game out of this. Would be better in my opinion.
Great concept and beautiful visuals. Game mechanics distilled to their minimum, and it works great. Well worth a number of hours of your time.

This is a fun land grabing game, but with one big change, the land under your feet providing you with resources might just slip from your feet and fall into a pile of black mist and take you down with it.

It is unique I'll give it that, but its poor graphics and lack of animations really ruin the game.

On top of all of this the differences between nations seems slim to none.

Overall I'd recommend against buying.
Unseal strategy/puzzle game. I hate to criticize those who try something new but this game failed to hold my interest past the point of learning how to play it.
A simple, yet satisfying strategy game with good multiplayer.

This is a great little game that will keep you going back for more, its addictive gameplay, although i could only play a few levels before my head was hurting. It seems there is not much of a multiplayer population for this game. Which is a big lettdown for me, as there is only computer left to play.

reviewerDisplayName: <CH> M λ S S I V
reviewText: Great strategy game, with many surprising tactitcs. It's like a cool board game...

Quite possibly the best board game that can't exist in the real world. Very simple and easy to play, but you'll quickly see the complex strategies you'll need to master to defeat the craftier opponents. A great game to play against the computer or friends!
its an interesting phone game. not a good one to have on your gaming pc, honestly. god bored pretty quickly, but i assume i would play more of it if I was in a subway going to work.
Nice turn-based strategy game, very original and funny.
Simple, beautiful strategy.  An excellent implementation of easy to learn

GreedCorp is a very interesting title. Players battle over the most important resource of all. LAND! Unfortunately, under all the land is just sky. So every time you destroy land you fall into oblivion! This game has some pretty awesome vibes to it. The gameplay  mechanics are deffinately new and fun. There are multiple corporations battling over what little land is left. This game has a beefy single player campaign, you won't be dissapointed! ~PR0XIDIAN
ok
More of a logical puzzle than a pure strategy game, Greed can shine when played against online opponents. Entertaining and colourful,  a good entry-level title for kids.

A good little turn-based strategy, almost like a board game.\nBut it's incredibly hard (at least for me), even on the first maps it seems that the computer always makes the perfect step, and if you make one mistake you lost. After getting to the second world I gave up, could not collect enough points to go further.\nIt's a nice game for hardcore strategy gamers who like to suffer.

Greed Corp is a fun game that just allows you to challenge your strategy skills and outdo other players while, basically, buidling an empire over some land. Not thrilling, but it kills time. Definitely worth a checking out.

A videót nézve megtetszett már a játék, főleg az első másodpercek. Ahogy elindítottam a játékot, majd megcsináltam az első lépéseket ez az érzés csak fokozódott. A játék lenyűgöző, egyszerű a kivitelezés, de a játékélmény annál jobb. Egy rossz döntés és törheti az ember a fejét, hogyan vergődik ki a csávából. Elgondolkodtató a játék viszont a zenei aláfestés feloldja ezt egy kicsit. Na, hogy is fejezzem ki magam, ez egy igazi stratégia és mindenkinek aki csak egy kicsit is a műfaj kedvelője ajánlom, remek kis game :D
A strategic, turn based game with a cute backstory. It's like monopoly, everyone except for one will leave in tears of their friends backstabbing them. By the way the campaign is really hard! 9/10
Great game. Almost no one is on multiplayer. However, if you are looking for a well made short game, then this is your game.

This game is surprisingly fun. Watching the world get destroyed is way more enjoyable than it should be!

Easy to learn, difficult to master turn-based strategy. Within the first section of the campaign, you will know how to do every single action in the game, and when a game's controls and interface are this accessible, gameplay really does boil down to pure strategy, which is exactly how a great strategy game should be.

Solid strategy game.

Some neat gameplay mechanics, but, honestly, it wasn't my kind of thing. The pacing is pretty slow and the tutorial is laboriously long (I spent more than half my time in the tutorial), resulting in a slow game with an overabundance of functionality all thrown at you at the same time.
This game is awesome and could use all the players it can get!

Greed corp is a fun little RTS. Its a little unsophisticated (If you're crazy about Starcraft, I say stick to Starcraft) but for someone a little more casual like me who feels daunted by the depth of SC but still wants to play an RTS, this is it.\n\nThe best part about the game is the slowly fragmented and shrinking land, which adds a cool level of movement strategy to it. I'd say its worth the full price.
Turn based strategy with gorgeous graphics, it's like that game online called Dice Wars" but with more strategy and better graphics."
